Other providers, such as hospitals and some pharmacies, are giving the Pfizer vaccine. These other providers may also be offering the Johnson and Johnson vaccine, which is currently not authorized for those under 18 years of age. If you are 12-17 years of age, please check vaccines.gov or contact the provider to see which vaccine is offered before scheduling your appointment.

Delaware has expanded vaccine eligibility to all individuals 16 and older. People can join a wait list online to request appointments. Those who receive invitations for an appointment can schedule them online. They also can schedule appointments through pharmacies.
 
 The state is working with pharmacies, medical providers, hospital systems, employers and other organizations to distribute shots.
age policy description (new): In May, The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) amended Pfizer-BioNTech?? Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) to expand use of its vaccine to include youth ages 12-15. On August 23, the FDA formally approved the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine for individuals 16 and older, and changed the vaccine?? name to COMIRNATY. There was not enough data at this time to extend full approval to cover persons 12-15 or a third dose for the immunocompromised, so the EUA for Pfizer and COMIRNATY both, remains in place, covering all populations originally included in the EUA. Once additional data is available, it is expected that full approval for other categories will be granted. If you received a first, or both doses of the vaccine of Pfizer, and will eventually need either a third or booster dose of the vaccine, you do not need to re-start the vaccine series now that the vaccine?? name has changed to COMIRNATY. Below you can learn more about vaccinations for those under age 16, and see answers to frequently asked questions about the vaccine and safety, fertility and more.
